title-group.article-title: Developmental Origins of Health and Disease
title-group.subtitle: The Role of Human Milk in Preventing Disease in the 21st Century

article-meta.aff: 1School of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Faculty of Science, The University of Western Australia, Perth, Australia
2School of Paediatrics and Child Health, The University of Western Australia, Perth, Australia
3Developmental Origins of Health and Disease (DOHaD) Consortium, Western Australia

author-notes.corresp: Donna T. Geddes, School of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Faculty of Science, The University of Western Australia, M310, 35 Stirling Highway, Perth 6009, Western Australia Email: donna.geddes@uwa.edu.au

kwd-group.kwd: developmental origins of health and disease

body.p: Over the past 50 years, there has been a dramatic rise in a diverse range of chronic noncommunicable diseases (NCDs), which has resulted in over 36 million deaths per year and accounted for more than 60% of all global deaths.1 Among the most common of these NCDs are heart disease, metabolic disease (obesity and type 2 diabetes), cancer, allergies and other immune diseases, asthma and chronic lung diseases, mental illness, and chronic liver and renal diseases, many of which are linked to prenatal and antenatal nutrition. At least 9 million of all preventable NCD deaths are in younger people, in their “prime” years of life. An astounding 80% of all NCD-related deaths occur in the developing, underprivileged regions of the globe, and without action, 52 million deaths are projected annually by 2030.

The early environment during pregnancy, lactation, and early childhood can determine physiological, structural, immune, metabolic, and behavioral development. It can also modify response patterns that influence future disease susceptibility and therefore have the potential to reduce NCDs.2 It is therefore logical and cost effective to focus on disease-prevention strategies in early life, in particular during the “first 1000 days”3 (from conception through the first years of infancy), when they are likely to have substantial impact. This is a core mandate of the interdisciplinary Developmental Origins of Health and Disease (DOHaD) movement. The International Society for DOHaD is composed of representatives of research and public policy stakeholders from Europe, North America, and the Pacific Rim, as well as developing countries. The International Society for DOHaD promotes research into the fetal and developmental origins of disease by involving scientists from many backgrounds. Their aims are to support a global research strategy to explore early human development with respect to disease later in life as well as promote the development and implementation of public health policies to prevent chronic disease.4 The urgency of this situation and the impact of early nutrition are reflected by increased numbers of publications reviewing early infant feeding practices and the appropriate methods of scientific research required to investigate mechanisms of protection afforded by early nutrition.5-11

It is not clear whether the effects of early nutrition on NCD risk are caused by metabolic derangements, psychosocial factors, or a combination of both,7 and many ethical, cultural, and methodological issues hamper the study of nutritional impact in the first 2 years of life. The protective effects of breastfeeding from infectious disease are well documented in prospective studies, particularly in developing countries, where infant morbidity and mortality have been reduced, leading to increased infant survival rates. These studies provide an opportunity to determine the incidence of NCDs in relation to breastfeeding and early protection from infection.12 In this context, human milk (HM) contains a host of bioactive factors including hormones, growth factors, neuropeptides, and anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory agents that compensate, either directly or indirectly, for the immaturity of the human infant.13 Thus, because it influences many physiological systems, HM is the first and most important source of nutrition and protection for the infant. It is this complexity that hampers investigation of the mechanisms by which HM influences infant health in both the short and long term.

Metabolic syndrome predisposes individuals to developing type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease (CVD). It is defined as a constellation of abnormal physical and laboratory findings that the person has central obesity (according to ethnic specific values for waist circumference) and any 2 of the following factors: elevated triglycerides, blood pressure, and fasting glucose; or reduced HDL cholesterol.14 Breastfeeding has been implicated in a reduction of risk of metabolic syndrome in a dose-dependent manner from 3 to 18 years of age.15 Chilean adolescents have also been shown to have decreased risk of metabolic syndrome if breastfed for longer than 90 days.16 It is intriguing that recent observations suggest the quality and/or type of the fat intake of infants may be integral to this effect,5 which raises the possibility that the protective effect of breastfeeding is mediated through this pathway.

HM has been shown to reduce the risk of obesity, although it is unclear whether this effect is mediated via components in HM, the mode of feeding, or both. The major macronutrients (protein, fat, and carbohydrates) have all been associated with risk of NCD; protein has been investigated the most. The protein content of formula is greater than that of HM. The amino acid profile of formula does not match the requirements of the infant, which necessitates increased total consumption of protein to ensure adequate intake of all the essential amino acids.7 Formula-fed infants differ in their growth and tend to be longer and heavier, and have higher body mass index than their breastfed counterparts.17 Further, higher protein intakes in the first year of life are associated with higher body mass index at 2 years of age,18 and high protein intake at weaning has been associated with NCDs, which strongly suggests that the low protein content of HM throughout the introduction of complementary foods is a contributing factor to the decreased risk of obesity in breastfed children.6 Taking into account the prevalence of high protein intakes at weaning in many western countries (above current recommendations) and their adverse effects, one must question the evidence for the safety and efficacy of follow-on milks in these settings as opposed to longer durations of breastfeeding during the first 1000 days of life.6

Because of large differences in the cholesterol content of HM and formula,19 breastfed infants have higher total blood cholesterol concentrations than formula-fed infants, yet in adolescence, those who were breastfed as infants exhibit lower cholesterol levels. The modest magnitude of the difference between HM and formula (0.2 mmol/L difference for adults) translates to a 10% decrease in the incidence of CVD.20 Further, exclusive breastfeeding conferred the greatest reduction in adult cholesterol.19 A minimal difference in cholesterol levels of children and adolescents suggests that the benefit of HM may not be apparent until later in life. Small reductions in systolic and diastolic blood pressure associated with breastfeeding may be significant from a population perspective,21 however, other studies have so far shown no effect of breastfeeding on blood pressure,22-24 which suggests the possibility of residual confounding factors.

The reduction in the risk of type 2 diabetes and the lower fasting insulin concentration associated with breastfeeding25 have been attributed to bioactive components in HM. Insulin and IGF-I levels of breastfed infants are lower than those of their formula-fed counterparts,26,27 which is assumed to be related to the lower levels of protein in HM, although it is likely more complex than expected.6 In contrast, recent studies show no effect of breastfeeding or breastfeeding duration on plasma glucose concentration or risk of type 2 diabetes.28 These studies were conducted in low- and middle-income countries where breastfeeding was prevalent, which may partly explain the findings. However, a new study has found an association between breastfeeding duration and 2-hour plasma glucose concentrations in a glucose tolerance test in 9-year-old Indian children.29 Clearly, more investigation is warranted in this area.

Although breastfeeding leads to reductions in risk factors associated with CVD, the effects of breastfeeding on CVD are not consistent. A systematic review showed no effect of breastfeeding on mortality caused by CVD.30 However, a follow-up study of women in the Nurses’ Health Study found those who had been breastfed had a small reduction in risk for any CVD.31 Inconsistent results between studies may be a result of recall bias for exclusivity and duration of breastfeeding, as well as limited availability of infant nutrition data in retrospective cohorts.32 Clearly, clarification of the effect of breastfeeding on CVD is necessary.

In a number of studies, breastfeeding has been linked to better cognitive outcomes,33 however, a meta-analysis of observational studies of term infants found no differences in the children’s performance when controlling for maternal intelligence.34 However, data from the PROBIT trial showed that improved breastfeeding rates through promotion were associated with a 5.9-point increase in IQ and better reading and writing performance in the children at age 6.5 years,35 which provides strong evidence that exclusive and extended breastfeeding improves cognitive development. In this context, the effect of the types of fat consumed on brain development are fascinating, especially given the dramatic neurodevelopmental changes that occur prenatally and in the first 3 to 4 months of life36 and that fatty acid accumulation in the brain exponentially increases in the first 24 months.37 Indeed, dietary supplementation of docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) appears to enhance cognitive development in breastfed infants, in particular those born preterm,38 and high levels of maternal fish consumption are associated with increased levels of DHA in HM.39 In this context, approximately 85% of the fatty acids in HM are derived from the diet, which allows enormous potential for dietary manipulation.40 Further, children with a FADS genotype that is associated with lower long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acid synthesis derive greater benefits from breastfeeding measured by IQ at school age than those who had a greater ability to convert polyunsaturated fatty acids.41

The effect of infant feeding on adult health is proposed to be a result of early nutrition, which permanently influences functional programming. However, an alternative mechanism may be that duration of breastfeeding, maternal diet, and the nature of complementary foods introduced at weaning may determine food preferences and dietary behavior later in life.19 Although there is evidence that taste preferences are influenced by maternal diet during pregnancy and can be altered during early infancy,42-45 there remains the possibility that breastfed infants have healthier dietary patterns as a result of parental influences. Breastfeeding exposes infants to a range of flavors derived from the maternal diet that are more variable than those experienced by formula-fed infants, which may influence later taste preferences.42,46 Indeed, breastfed infants tend to have a greater acceptance of foods, a finding that is consistent with breastfed infants exhibiting healthier dietary patterns later in life.47 Although it is also known that genetic, physiological, and metabolic factors influence taste responses,48 specific taste molecules (T1R2, T1R3, Gagust, and TRPM5) have been shown to be reduced in adults who have type 2 diabetes compared to those who do not;49 the mechanism by which this occurs is unknown. As yet, the expression of these taste-sensing proteins has not been investigated in either children or adults with respect to exposure to breast milk, but such research would be worth pursuing, given that taste preference may well contribute to the long-term health benefits of breastfeeding through this pathway. Future studies that account for the effects of social patterning are also required.

Despite the fact that breastfeeding leads to a reduction in risk of NCDs later in life, few mothers meet the World Health Organization recommendations for exclusive breastfeeding of 6 months. The timing of introduction and quality of complementary foods is incredibly variable between developed and developing countries, as well as different cultures. Of particular concern is the use of cow’s milk and sweetened fluids, and the fact that formula-fed infants tend to be introduced to other foods sooner than breastfed infants.7 Also, marked discrepancies in the types of food introduced appear to be influenced by the media, advertising, local culture, economic status, and in poorer regions, food availability.8,11 It is therefore imperative that breastfeeding be promoted during the introduction of complementary foods.7,32

In summary, early life is an opportune time for intervention. Prevention is the ultimate approach to reducing the burden of NCDs, and there is great potential for improving health through the promotion of breastfeeding and feeding of appropriate complementary foods, which would thus provide wide social and economic benefits.50 Coordinated interdisciplinary strategies across multiple sectors of infant and maternal nutrition such as research, health promotion, and policy will serve to elucidate the mechanisms by which breastfeeding reduces the risk of NCDs in both the infant and mother and allow more effective implementation of strategies to improve infant health in both the short and long term.
